Pros: Great benefits, mostly great fellow workers, nice building
Cons: It can be great, depending on what group you are in. Otherwise, it can be absolutely a dead end and awful place. Management is a pointless overpaid oligarchy, controlled by europe, with no power to influence any real change. It is incredibly ironic they are located (currently) on "innovation" campus yet have literally no control over their destiny. Over 10 years, the employee review system slowly went from legitimate accountability for actions, to simply "who is a favorite." The same goes for promotions. It all depends on what manager your are friends with, and what group you are in. The worst group by far is the repairs organization, which unfortunately is also the most stable if you would like to stay employed. (I left voluntarily) In this group, you are considered a 3rd rate engineer despite more work output than any "program" group employee. Also, you will be required to give up your nights, weekends, holidays on a perpetual basis for "the business." Family time, personal time does not matter to management if you are in this group. The rest of the office will enjoy their weekends off, and their 1/2 day fridays, but nope, not if you're in repair! Often, those who have "signature delegations" who can sign off on structural repairs of aircraft, are pressured to sign off on repairs despite not being able to prove structural capability. Even if the repair is analyzed properly and shown "bad," next thing you know it is approved by "the German hand wave." This essentially means, that since you can't show damage or a repair as structurally acceptable, you simply say "by engineering judgment" it is okay to fly! Wohoo! Want to know what management said in an actual meeting in front of structural engineers? "It's not like planes are falling out of the sky." This was literally during the 737 Max crisis where planes DID fall out of the sky. There are numerous times I should have "blown the whistle" on things but I feared I would be fired. Tell me one whistleblower that has ever actually remained anonymous and kept their job. I still debate doing it because of the constant managerial push to disregard safety and proper analysis in pursuit of speed and output. I am incredibly grateful to be free of this toxic job. To give examples, analysis data quite often was either *MISSING*, inaccessible, unreadable, full of analysis errors or completely useless. Rarely could any of us as engineers have real faith in the data we were using to "analyze" repairs. Not only that, but we would use data for YEARS, then be told that those reports were the WRONG ONES!!! Did we go back and check old repairs? NOPE! You will also be beaten over the head why you are so inefficient. Perpetual understaffing and inability of management to understand the repairs workflow operations has lead to complete employee burnout, and incredible inefficiency. There are truly some of the best engineers I've known that work in repairs. However nearly all want out, but are trapped in aircraft or near retirement. There are many other things I could put out there, but at least this should be enough to say you've been warned. Oh, and contractors? Don't think for a second they'll hold up their end of the bargain once you're onboarded into repairs. If you hire for a particular night or weekend shift, the reality is, they will put you wherever they want whenever they want. This is why even the contractors quit.

Summary: Great for early career - not an option for advanced / senior career
Pros:
If you are starting your career as an engineer or in a function like communications or sales, Airbus is the place to go to in the Aerospace and Defence industry. The know how is excellent and there is a lot of work to do. However, this is only true for entry and early career  level. Always good to have the Airbus brand in your CV.
The award winning Leadership Academy is really cool to be part of.
Cons:
If you are advanced or senior in your career you will find a minefield of backdrops - here are a few to consider: the culture is very discriminating unless you are French in FRA or German in GER. Politics is core: the French networks (eg "Poly") rule and as a foreigner you have little chance to get invited to them - which literally puts a hard stop on your career & progress in your  work wherever you are. If you consider a job outside France or Germany be warned: despite the luring promises of HR - there is no career advancement for you abroad - period! Must principle: Knowledge & Expertise counts nothing! Networks and saving your boss's job is everything. Must not: Believe Airbus will accelerate your career - in fact it will slow it down, as Airbus is 10-20 years behind modern leadership, technologies, workplace environment, tools, IT, HR, etc.
For advanced career it is NOT an advantage to have Airbus in your CV any longer, as (well informed) recruiters know that you literally lost your cutting edge in the years you spent surviving in an old fashioned industrial dinosaur - take cutting edge engineering or marketing as an example.

The people mostly, Airbus is full of intelligent individuals who are great to work with. The benefits given to employees through numerous schemes are second to none. Development is a very important aspect of Airbus and the company will do all they can to further support your training/development aspirations. Also Airbus really is a 'job for life' with the company outlook always expanding and improving.
Cons: The biggest con i can think of is that with such a big company and many employees at all different levels there can sometimes be a 'divide' between corporate levels, such as between upper management and the employees directly on the factory floor. Summary: One of the most interesting places to work
Pros: Everyone at Airbus is inspired by the product and identifies with it. Being motivated is easy because of the team spirit and the sense of a common goal. You always have the feeling of working at the forefront of technology. The company develops at a fast pace and things change on a day-to-day basis.
Cons: Because you work in a large company, you can easily get the feeling that you are a small cog in a large wheel. For a variable and interesting career in the long term you should look around in other departments and initiate a change. The good side is, that it is easily done having in mind the dimensions of Airbus.

Pros: Lots of different opportunities in vast areas

Summary: Interesting aerospace industry and work, great work life balance, slow pace of work in frustrating environment
Pros: Really interesting industry and some of the most interesting engineering projects available. Work consists of Telecommunication satellites, Science missions, ground systems and launchers. Lots of opportunity to work in any imaginable area of a large multinational engineering company, Great work life balance due to flexitime and paid overtime. Good starting place to get a foot hold in the aerospace industry and/or other EADS positions and proactive people tend to do well.
Cons: Little pressure to deliver can make work very slow. Huge level of process, inadequate environment and IT infrastructure and flat management structure can make work life very frustrating. Large multinational company results in slow change and a tendency to do things they way they have always been done. Change is not encouraged. Due to flat structure, its very difficult to get promotions in management. Little encouragement or pressure to build skills and continue to develop. If you are looking to be under pressure, constantly challenged, want quick promotion and high pay prospects then look else where

Summary: Sunset of a Great European Aircraft Story.
Pros: Because developing commercial aircraft is the only thing you want to do in life. And you absolutely want to work in Europe, nowhere else. Then Airbus is certainly your best bet. Indeed, there aren't many other bets.
Cons:
If you are an engineer, you will most suffer low morale. This may seem odd in an industry built on the back of engineering creativity. Indeed, you will hear Airbus senior management and recruiters bemoan the fact that they can't recruit enough suitable engineers. But the reality is, They want mediocre engineers, prepared to produce mediocre work, and satisfied with mediocre reward. They will SAY they highly value engineers. But their actions bely their words.

There are bright spots. Some local departments are very well led and managed. But even excellent managers cannot protect you from the stifling bureaucracy. A few people do seem to thrive in the environment, and have meteoric career paths. But they are not the norm.

Summary: Amazing place to learn and grow
Pros: Airbus has an amazing culture wherein any employee at any position has direct access to the top management. The management is also very transparent about all the decisions taken at local as well as global level. Ample amount of opportunities are offered to employees who want to make a true difference and there is no limit what you can achieve.
Cons: There are really no cons of working at Airbus.

Summary: Bureaucracy and policy used as an excuse for lazy middle management
Pros: Exciting projects, large enough company to allow development of a social network. High responsibility permitted as soon as you are willing to take it, if not before. Senior management are passionate about the company and its future.
Cons: Large, wallowing, bureaucratic beast mindset. "Yes we know it doesn't work, but that's the way it's always been done, we can't change it." Low ability to compensate anyone who stands out from the pack- herd mentality, dragged down by the lowest common denominators. Middle managers hide behind policy as an excuse for not sticking their neck out or making difficult decisions. Low salaries with the attitude that all staff are expendable as in the space industry, people are lining up to take their place. Not enough staff, so workload is high. Anyone with talent, drive or ambition is eventually forced to leave to fulfil their potential, leaving the dregs and the doormats behind, reinforcing the general stagnant negativity.

Summary: Stable with good benefits, but lower end salary range
Pros:
Great for early stage career, with lots of training, lots of movements opening up opportunities for the bold, willing to relocate - so again great for the young.
If you are in and content, then it is really good, with generous benefits, and fairly good job security. Good work/ life balance.
Cons: With experience individuals tend to get stuck in their roles, seemingly happily drawing the lower than average salary for half a day's work. If you want more and consider your career to be on the up then its not so easy to move around within Airbus, and get recognition for any additional effort or responsibility that you take on.

Pros:
Standard week is 35 hours. Flexible hours start between 6am and 1pm and work a minimum of 5.25 hours plus 45 min lunch Monday to Thursday and 4 hours no lunch on Friday.
Some home working possible but varies job to job, depends on role and manager.
Good benefits can 'buy' and extra weeks holiday. Childcare vouchers, cycle to work scheme.
Cons:
Set up and operation is poor. Allocation of budgets, random cutting of budgets, booking codes a nightmare. Finance dictate bad ways of operating, every department used a different tool and 2 or 3 departments all thinking they are running the budget for a project... No control, ridiculous amounts of time lost to just working out what's going on with the money when it should all be transparent.
A lot of managers are more in keeping with the 1950s than 2010s. 
Not always clear how to progress. HR are hopeless

Pros: Very well organized industry, as well as top team development and individual development for career employees of the company. Quality in every aspect of the word, and working there is very rewarding thus improving performance and output of employees.
Cons: no one would Pay is average, but we are talking about the German system, although I loved working there, I would earn more contracting Overseas for American companies or in the U.S. If the pay would be hire for the middle class jobs no one would  leave this company as they are very well organized and good to the employess, very family oriented and professional.

Pros: I intended to be at Airbus for about 2 years and have ended up being there for 12 so far. I think this is quite common. It is a very big company and if you want to grow you need to be open minded, to network and to look for new roles every 2 to 3 years. It is a real trans national company which makes a cool product
Cons:
Brexit us very worrying for the long term future of Airbus commercial in the uk. The future could be fantastic but equally the sites could disappear in 10 to 15 years time. A lot of this depends on how plugged I  the uk top management are to the European centre (worrying thought!)
The company is also bureaucratic and political due to aerospace regulations and it's size and complexity. You need to be prepared to understand and navigate thus

Pros: Given the low level of experience prior to the internship, the amount of responsibility was steadily increased over the course of the year, with freedom to work on a variety of interesting in the R&T department.
Cons: Low pay, which makes living difficult given the expense of living in Bristol. No real connection between the internship and the graduate scheme, there isn't an incentive to come back.

Pros:

great products, and most employees are proud of them
Cons: can be slow (united nations syndrom: strong stakeholder management needed as senior management decisions are not necessarily followed)

You are given real work during the apprenticeship as opposed to practice or meaningless work, you are contributing to the company and making a difference. There is plenty of support from Airbus, the college and the university. Lots of activities and trips to get involved in.
Cons: Not much calrity from the appretice line managers. Ocassionaly treated as kids rather than emplyees. But you are treated as full time employees by the core placement managers and teams.

They cook up stories and manipulate the management largely comprising of expats, bigtime.

The company has more activities, work fields and offers than you can use, realize or participate.  International environment, good sport offers. Your patience and endurance is daily challenged.
Cons: Big burocracy, expensive processes, no company culture, no dicipline, volatile company organisation (permant organisation changes, inclusive sites). It seems to be an own world and universe, nothing to do with the work and performance of SMEs. The company is very France oriented and dominated. If you want to see what you did achieve at the end of the day, it is the wrong place.

Pros: Internal career has many possibilities in terms of changing department. Good benefits and good salaries specially at entry level. Company really focus on people.
Cons: Typical issues of companies that big. In general terms, things take time although there is a trend to change this aspect. In addition, the sector is mainly divided in two big players but again the future seems different.

- decent pay
- good work-life balance
- not too much stress
- public servant kind of job
- you wont be fired if you don't perform
Cons:
- you climb the latter, if you don't screw up (succeeding is not important), which means that you shouldn't fail, which leads to: no risk taking and no decision making
- no strategy in place or totally disconnected from people working

- constant re-organisation (at least every 2 years)

Pros: Large Aircraft design & build opportunities. Good career progress for self driven individuals. Airbus in the UK employs world class engineers (evident when dealing with subcontract houses & Teir 1 suppliers). Generally good work life balance, i.e. little pressure on when holidays should be taken.
Cons: lack or "care" for employees, massive differences in treatment of employees between sites, some of these are perceived, some are real (i.e french contract employees don't take xmas holidays out of allowance). Slightly less self driven or pushy individuals can be "forgotten" doing a good & steady job.. you have to push for opportunities. Government politics play too much of a role in the company.

Summary: The best company I have ever worked for.
Pros: I worked for Airbus for over 12 years, it was a great job, great environment, and great people, and was gutted when my role came to an end.
Cons: None that I can think of.

Pros: The company is successful and has an excellent portfolio of aerospace equipment which is world famous. I am involved in the manufacture of satellites. The job offers many opportunities to explore in detail the design of the equipment, its manufacture, testing, and operation. Many different roles are available. A good work life balance and flexible working
Cons: The company is large, slow and inflexible. There are a multitude of arcane internal systems many of which are internally developed and ancient. It is easy to get stuck in a rut in the company and the management structure is deep and opaque which can lead to cynicism and cronyism. There does not appear to be a mechanism to reward good performance which can lead to laziness. For a leading aerospace company, it's amazing how inefficient some of the internal processes are.

Summary: It's on a wrong track right now
Pros:
A lot of expertise and qualifications to learn upon, especially for those who really are into aviation 
Good work-life balance, solid social benefits
Generally  good working atmosphere and great people to work with
Cons: Wide use of outsourcers and subcontractors who blindly follow routine and don't care about result. Too much management levels mean long and complex approval process and a notable amount of people in critical positions lack aeronautical knowledge and understanding of what they do/should do. Poor career perspectives, unless you are connected on executive level - personal assistant seems to be the most promising position. Solutions which are aimed to decrease bureacracy only increase it instead.

Pros: Good experience within a large multinational engineering firm.
Cons:
Workload can vary greatly. It is sometimes quiet for long periods of time. You can ask for work until your blue in the face and if you mention this you will be told to be more proactive. 

The work can sometimes seem pointless and be given without context, which can make some of the experience redundant. Was the work even used and how? Sometimes tasks seem to be given for the sole purpose of keeping you busy.

How good your internship is depends heavily on the department you are in.

Summary: Be cautious when considering this company, unless you are an engineer.
Pros:
Nice people in entry and mid level positions who obviously care about producing quality goods and services.

Engineers are highly sought and valued.
Cons:
Poor management decsions regarding annual raise reviews:  Management paid out full bonuses when goals were missed by 30%, allowing executives to get full bonus.  Within weeks, company laid off more than 50% of defense focused employees.

Poor Leadership in most areas of Test and Services division.  Significant cronyism within division executive circles, which were ignored by corporate executive team in VA.

Extremely poor transition when merging 2 small companies into one.  
Policies were not equally enforced between major sites.

Summary: Culturally diverse and professionally very fulfilling and gratyfying place to work.
Pros: Culturally diverse, involved with industry standard technology and engineering tools and practices. Very good culture of developing and nurturing its people and a very competitive benefits package.
Cons: Due to the large and diverse coorporate organisation and challenging customer and commercial requirements the working environment can be very political, which detracts from the core engineering deliverable.

Location: in Portsmouth, South East England, England, England
Pros:
Friendly colleagues
Impressive end product (not that you'll ever see much of it)
Cons: Talking in acronyms is common to any sphere of work, but here it really does rule the day and I expect many of the misguided souls who work here feel proud to be 'on the inside'. Astrium is a company of one-trick ponies grinding their way slowly through meetings about meetings not to mention the endless paperwork. It's amazing to think that working products actually emerge at the end of this slow and inefficient process. Pay is in the lower quartile relative to other sectors and career progression poor. So many people here seem trapped with no transferable skills and boy don't HR know this. Ok for contractors as a last resort but again pay rates are low. If you really must work in the space sector, seek out opportunities in Canada and the USA.

Pros:

Some nice people

- The company is cutting back on projects and development, making it hard to believe that there will be any good opportunities for a former intern returning as a graduate.

Summary: Excellent company in a constant change process
Pros: Plenty international career opportunities within the company, interesting product, great work environment, standing of the brand (in particular in France), great works council.
Cons: Limited attrition of workers and employees once hired by Airbus leads to a relatively slow career progress. Average salaries for newcomers do not attract high flyers.

Summary: Passionate people, interesting projects and all the pros and cons of a large organisation.

Part of a large international group with lots of opportunities. Like any company teams vary form one area to another but I have been very satisfied with the support from management and learning opportunities I've experienced in the company. The company is filled with very passionate people my experience in the space systems division has given me the opportunity to work with some of the most knowledgeable experts in the field.

Employees are generally quite well looked after with plenty of vacation time and on many sites flexible working hours.
Cons: Although mobility and career progression is highlighted as a top priority by management poor HR policies and small minded local politics can cause blocking points.

Cons: Despite the multinational culture of the overall business, each individual BU has its own idiosyncrasy and therefore might be reluctant in adhering to the overall business culture.

Pros: You are able to accumulate hours and later take the extra hours in holidays, good place to learn and very international
Cons: The company is very corporate and sometimes it isnt easy to move up quikly in a position. Not always your opinion is heard to better something

Flexi-time system helpful (when you can take time off, that is).  
Pays well.

Complex hierarchical organizational structure which has got worse since the previous Astrium days,

Pros: Talented people, exciting projects, international exposure, lots of responsibility at an early stage, good benefits, work life balance possible, decent amount of travel

Pros: The best aerospace company in the world. High Tech company. Very wide product and competence portfolio. Substantial research and innovation investment. Very diverse. Develops its people. Many many different areas to work.
Cons: Huge company size, heavily regulated sectors, and safetyu critical products, requiere processess and organization more complex than other smaller companies. We work very hard to reduce that.

Pros: A small company located on the industrial side of Temecula. It is very easy to get to know the team that you work with/for at the company.  Location is ideal for commuters.
Cons: Blatant violations by specific people in Management to keep unqualified personnel on payroll for personal reasons.  HR is unresponsive and does not advocate for the employees, but instead ensures that Management has freedom to act as it will for 'the greater good of the company'. (Sales and productivity.)

Summary: Great place to be as a student
Pros:
- Professional Environment

- Company politics (some might say thats a con, but I learned a great deal about them)
Cons:

- Many employees worked there for 20+ years => sometimes you can feel a lack of freshness

Pros:

-High-tech machinery and processes.
Cons:

Pros: Good experience, got to see the ins and out of business. Opportunity to learn and ask questions. Good work balance.
Cons: As an intern you are given task but not a great resposinsibilty. Was in and out of meetings and some were not effective.

Summary: Excellent working conditions that are only neglected by people who never worked for any other company.
Pros: Pride to work in a company that produces remarkable products with very high quality standards. Employees enjoy good and competitive salaries, especially when they are compared within the local area. Job security is second only to the public sector.
Cons: At the end it is just a job.

Pros: International, lots of people are bi- or tri-lingual at least, big melting pot of nationalities Generally good flexibility on working hours (varies by department though) Good opportunities for mobility if you're happy to push for them and be flexible Excellent training courses Airbus Commercial Aircraft has excellent staff council Airbus Commercial Aircraft has excellent internal restaurants
Cons:

Despite lots of task about mobility there are lots of job hoggers 
Need personal network to progress (not merit based)
No new programmes in sight so refocus on processes in main group companies
Decreasing opportunities for progression due to reduction in middle management positions/tighter rules regarding promotions
Department culture very dependent on boss  (personality, nationality, etc) - big variations across services and the company

Pros:
Interesting sector with a large of subjects to discover
Good relationships with the co-workers coming from different European countries
Thriving company
Cons: The work is not always very exciting. The food could be better, especially on monday, when they don't have fish.

Pros: 35h per week. Over hours paid.

Summary: Excellect technical work and colleagues, a well run corporation and dream job

Exciting projects. 
Professional corporate structure. 
Fairness in dealing with problems and issues in the workplace and in personal life.
Excellent facilities.

Cons: Cross cultural ways of working is one of the major challenges as one has to deal.with people of different  nationalities and working styles.

Summary: Great company to work for with many opportunities to grow.
Pros: Many development opportunities, exciting projects and lots of nice people to work with.
Cons: Sometimes processes can be overwhelming and  certain things can take forever to progress. The company is so big it is difficult to have visibility and understand the bigger picture.

Pros: Gain lots of knowledge about their products and services. Learn the MRO approach to solve technical issues on aircraft. Plenty of technical course offered to MRO staff.
Cons: More soft skills course should be offered to technical staff. Staff benefits should also be increased and reviewed in comparison to other aviation companies.

Summary: Great place to work at, but they don't really value Assistants
Pros:
Airbus is a great place to work at, plenty of opportunities and great professionals to collaborate with. They have high values and an awesome company culture.

Your daily work will allow you to meet people from all over the world, which is a very enriching experience, and actually they are now promoting liquid teams.

If you are looking for an innovative company, this is one of the best.
Cons:
They don't cover Executive or Personal Assistants with external candidates but for temporary positions.

Assistant positions are used as wildcards to relocate headcounts from other departments, even if the candidate doesn't posses the solid professional background a C manager or Senior Manager requires.

Pros:
Worklife balance
No pressure to  not take leaves (most of the people actually use the full leave quota and it is not considered issue at all in the company)
Opportunities are scarce for growth technical and otherwise but if you try and know where you want to go, its ok.
Cons:
Little too heavy on process for a large MNC.
Sometimes the process even gets in the way of doing the job.
Company puts lot of financial value of experience of employees and not on actual skill. (Younger ppl on an average get paid less even for doing 'exactly' same job as someone older)

Pros: Can live in London as the job is in Stevenage. Pay attention to employee development with frequent presentations, etc.
Cons: Small site only so everyone know everyone. Could expand a bit more in Stevenage

Summary: Lots of planning, no work being done.

Cons:
I worked at EADS D&S and they have been preparing documents for several years, without getting any actual work done. There was no product, not even an alpha version. Summary: Slow and Inefficient - Continually Hampered by Process Diktats

Frustrating place to work - Every aspect of this business is process driven, inefficient and seems to take forever. Yes, you've guessed it, the gullible management have let the consultants in to sell them a series of overpriced 'projects' delivered by 'expert consultants' with little knowledge about how the business actually works. 'Lean' is the latest buzzword - great when you're making cheap mass-produced widgets/cars (eg. Toyota) but is it really applicable to essentially a low-volume bespoke product? The very processes that management use to improve efficiency are the very processes that hamper efficiency when real people try to implement them. Extremely frustrating. I found myself spending 25% of my time on paper chases, trying to get various bits of paper signed by managers and QA staff that knew very little about what they are actually signing. Inevitably when project timescales slip, the engineers and technicians then get blamed for not doing the job quickly enough!
Lack of career opportunity - little real career development. Yes, they love to bestow inflated job titles such as 'Higher Senior Engineer' to make people feel good about their plight, but in reality this just means a marginal increase in salary and no paid overtime as you try to climb higher. In the end, I left to work for one of Astrium's customers - 60% instant increase in pay and now with real scope to develop my career.

Overall laid-back management, they trust you to do the job and don't ask too many questions.  However, they expect you to be productive.  
There are annual reviews, so you always know where you stand.
Being in the defense business, the company has a 9-80 schedule in which everyone has every other Friday off.
If you like travel, this could be the company for you as there can be lots of it.
The company has a worldwide presence and it is a feather in your hat to work at such a company.
From everything I hear, it is a better (less corporate) work environment than nearby competitor Boeing.
Cons:
The defense business is cyclical, hence there tend to be a lot of layoffs, followed by hiring sprees.  Not much in the form of advancement or promotions, unless you have been in the business for 20 years or more.  Promotions are not really formal, and usually come as a result of someone retiring.  There also are raise freezes as a result.  By the time you figure out how the business works, they have gotten a lot out of you.

There is a lot of travel involved, depending on your position.  If you like travel, this could be a pro for you.  However, decisions to travel are often made the last minute, hence it is hard to have a stable personal life at home. 

The business is a small world, hence there can be a small business mentality to things.
Most projects involve upgrading legacy projects and are headed by people in the business for 30 years or more.  This impairs creativity.

The management tends to not be clear about things when they change.

For those who like to compare companies in an industry, it is a step down from Lockheed Martin as far as work environment and being treated like a professional and advancing your career.
